posts.name: Tom Praisner
posts.cooked: Here is the simplified and cleaned-up version of the text: We are proud to present a highly effective solution by modifying the traditional elevator framework to reduce its structural complexity. The text describes the process of creating a simpler rigging system compared to extrusions, focusing on adding pulleys and changing the hardware. The key benefits include eliminating the need for machinebolts or matching-bolts on the pulleys, reducing the number of parts required, and simplifying the overall construction process. This allows for more efficient installation and maintenance. The solution involves using simple, 3D-printed pulleys and press-fit SDS elevator blocks, which make internal routing much cleaner. This approach ensures that lines run precisely parallel to the extrusion, minimizing tension variations and providing consistent performance during operation. Additionally, the use of durable materials such as PBT (polystyrene-butylene-tetrafluoroethylene) and easily-machined steel enables the creation of simple pulleys and press-fit adaptor components, further streamlining the manufacturing process. The final output demonstrates how this method achieves nearly perfect alignment of the rigging lines, a significant improvement over previous methods.

link_counts.title: Looking for experience rigging and powering continuous elevators with Dyneema rope

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked: Another user thinks this is a great idea and has implemented it already! What steps did they take to run the elevator rigging? They dropped the line down the tube with a small weight attached first. Now, can their method be used even after the elevator is fully assembled? There seems to be difficulty getting the line out of the tube since both tube plugs are still in place.

posts.name: Tom Praisner
posts.cooked: Ah, good question! Due to an assembly mistake, we rigged the elevator twice during construction. We sewed the lines through each elevator tube segment using carbon-fiber rods. The end of the UHMWPE line was taped to the tube to act as a needle. After mastering this method, each side took 5-10 minutes to install, and no elevator disassembly was needed.

link_counts.title: Amazon.com: (4) Pieces - 2mm x 1000mm Carbon Fiber RODS - Solid Pultruded Round Rods. Super High Strength for RC Hobbies, Drones, Special Projects - (4) Rods : Industrial & Scientific

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked: EXTREMLY IMPORTANTLY - DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION, NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLENATION), JUST THE CLEANED PARAGRAPH. I had the same idea right before kickoff XD. I looked up similar ideas but didn't find anything close to what I wanted. The main constraint was having to use only tube routers and belt saws without any CNC machines. I tried creating my own solution with bearing blocks but realized it wasn't feasible. My first attempt involved large billet bearing blocks, which didn't work. I asked for help, and someone suggested trying a different approach. After failing, I thought differently and came up with a new idea involving shorter bearing blocks. This led to a successful outcome.

posts.name: Tom Praisner
posts.cooked: We replaced some of the 3D-printed pulleys due to limitations with PLA. On our second iteration, we reduced the groove depth to allow thicker PLA, enabling the UHMWPE to run directly. It would be better to print them from something tougher than PLA, or machine them from aluminum.

posts.name: Tom Praisner
posts.cooked: This is an impressive and valuable initiative; specifically aimed at simplifying robust elevator construction. I apologize for missing your post on internal belt rigging.

Unfortunately, our CAD is not in a good place for release. Below is a recent post from one of our captains regarding plans for CAD release:

If we can get it to a good state, I think we will. We have not decided internally if we want to yet, but either way, it is not in a good state in terms of broken mates and unreflected physical changes right now. If you have any questions, feel free to ask! I will happily provide as many details as possible.

posts.name: Kevin
posts.cooked:
Heres the cleaned-up paragraph, preserving the original meaning while adhering to proper grammar and punctuation:

---

The spool features two green marks indicating where the extension strings attach. Red marks show the retraction string's attachment point, while yellow highlights the connection to the carriage. A blue depiction illustrates the string's flow direction.

The string descends from the spool, bends around two pulleys near the outside stage, ascends over a pulley on the bearing block, and then descends between the outside and first moving stage. This sequence repeats as the string moves through the first moving stage toward the innermost stage. Within the innermost stage, the string connects to tensioning loops visible in the photos.

The string traverses the "bottom" stage relative to this viewpoint before shifting between the bottom and middle stages. Additional photos depict the string running through various stages.

Please let me know if any corrections are needed.

---
